abstract.p: Russell Leigh Moses letter on proliferation of China 'experts' and China watchers

block.p: Aside from the increase in involvement of strategic studies experts as ''China watchers'' (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20), two other tendencies need to be mentioned.

For the sake of partisan controversy and ratings, the news media seek photogenic people who are then introduced as ''China experts'' and become identified in the mind of the public as shedding clear light on a murky subject. And many of the actual experts have left the field of China studies because of the decreasing number of academic jobs.
Aside from the increase in involvement of strategic studies experts as ''China watchers'' (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20), two other tendencies need to be mentioned.

For the sake of partisan controversy and ratings, the news media seek photogenic people who are then introduced as ''China experts'' and become identified in the mind of the public as shedding clear light on a murky subject. And many of the actual experts have left the field of China studies because of the decreasing number of academic jobs.

Because of their contact with China, Sinologists have always been aware of the country's historically closed culture and opaque political system. This training to be careful in analysis does not fit very well in an age where seemingly knowing, loud and partisan perspectives are elevated and celebrated.
RUSSELL LEIGH MOSES Portland, Ore., May 22, 2000
The writer is a visiting professor of international affairs at Portland State University.
